fields: Defined as the "2nd coming"
Parousia
People in purgatory pray to go to heaven. T or F?
F, they cannot pray and rely on alive people to do so for them.
What are the two types of judgement?

- General judgement
- Individual judgement
When it is decided that a person is going to hell/heaven/purgatory, which type of judgement is that?
Individual judgement
The word Church comes from the Greek ____, meaning ______ or ____
ekklesia  assembly or called-out ones
_____ represents the community of all baptized believers in Christ, forming the ______ with Jesus as its ____.
Church, Body of Christ, Head
The Church is a ______ - guided by the Holy Spirit and built on the foundation of the apostles, the Church is both a ____ institution and an _____ spiritual communion.
Spiritual Family, visible, invisible
Its origins trace back to Jesus Christ, continuing through the apostles and powerfully empowered by the _____ at Pentecost (Acts 2).
Founded by Christ, Holy Spirit

Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them... and teaching them to obey everything I
have commanded you.
Matthew 28:19320
3 Missions of the Church
Evangelization, Worship & Santification, Service & Justice
Proclaiming the Gospel and calling people to conversion and faith.
Evangelization
Celebrating sacraments and encouraging spiritual growth and holiness.
Worship & Sanctification
Caring for the marginalized and promoting peace and human dignity.
Service & Justice
Three Kinds of the Body of Christ
Physical, Eucharistic, Mystical

Refers to Jesus' historical human body, born of the Virgin Mary, which suffered, died, and rose in glory. This body reveals God9s love and saves humanity through His Passion. "The Word became flesh and dwelt among us." (John 1:14)
Physical Body of Christ (Historical)
Denotes Christ's real presence in the Holy Eucharist.
The Eucharistic Body of Christ (Sacramental)
Through _____, bread and wine become His Body and Blood at Mass, uniting believers intimately with Him. "This is my Body, which will be given up for you..." (Luke 22:19)
Transubstantiation

Represents the Church itself, where all baptized members are parts of Christ9s body, with diverse roles united by the Holy
Spirit. Christ is the Head, and believers are His unified Body. "Now you are the Body of Christ, and each one of you is a part of it." ( 1 Corinthians 12:27)
The Mystical Body of Christ
Three States of the Church
Militant, Suffering, Triumphant
Militant, Suffering, Triumphant in other words
Earth, Purgatory, Heaven
Living believers fighting the spiritual battle against sin. Their mission is to live in holiness and spread the Gospel.
Church Militant (Earth)
Souls undergoing purification before entering Heaven, aided by prayers from Earth.
The Church Suffering (Purgatory)
Saints in Heaven who have triumphed over sin, living in eternal joy with God and interceding for others.
The Church Triumphant (Heaven)
The Church is more than an organization; it is a living mystery rooted in _____. Whether on Earth, in Purgatory, or in Heaven, all are united in one body, with Christ at its ______.
divine love, center
Our shared mission is to bring ______ to the world and journey towards _____ with Him.
Christ's love, eternal life
Living in faith, fighting sin, spreading the Gospel
Militant Church
Believers on Earth
Militant Church
Undergoing purification, aided by prayers of the faithful
Church Suffering (Purgatory)
Souls in Purgatory
Suffering Church
United with God, interceding for others
Triumphant Church
Saints in Heaven
Triumphant Church
Jesus' actual, human body
Physical Body of Christ
Incarnation, Passion, Resurrection
Physical Body of Christ
Jesus present in consecrated bread and wine
Eucharistic Body of Christ
Real Presence in the Eucharist
Eucharistic Body of Christ
Unity in diversity within the Church
Mystical Body of Christ
"The Word became flesh and dwelt among us."
John 1:14
"This is my Body, which will be given up for you..."
Luke 22:19
"Now you are the Body of Christ, and each one of you is a part of it."
1 Corinthians 12:27
In which CLVED (1, 2, 3 or 4) is the Old Testament being the one focused on?
CLVED 1
What was the punishment Adam and Eve received after committing the first sin?
Death
What figure/concept is the main focus of CLVED 1?
God the Father
What was Jesus' "form" in CLVED 1?
Word
What figure/concept is the main focus of CLVED 2?
God the Son (Jesus)
What era of the bible is focused on in CLVED 2?
New Testament
If CLVED 1 is focused on {{c1::creation}}, CLVED 2 is focused on {{c2::salvation}}, while CLVED 3 is focused on {{c3::sanctification}}, and finally CLVED 4 is focused on {{c4::judgement}}.
What figure/concept is the focus of CLVED 3?
Holy Spirit
What era of the bible is focused on in CLVED 3?
The Church
What figure/concept is the focus of CLVED 4?
Morality
What is the "form" of Jesus in CLVED 2?

Flesh 

(The word became flesh)
This event signified the birth of the Church
Pentecost
This term means "to make holy"
Sanctify/Sanctification
This body reveals God's love and saves humanity through His Passion.
Physical Body of Christ
What type of body of Christ: "The Word became flesh and dwelt among us."
Physical Body of Christ (Historical)
What did Pneumatomachi teach about the Holy Spirit?
The Holy Spirit is a created being
Who spread Pneumatomachi and when?
Macedonius, 4th century
Which council condemned Pneumatomachi?
Council of Constantinople (381 AD)
What truth about the Holy Spirit does the Church affirm in response to Pneumatomachi?
The Holy Spirit is fully divine, consubstantial with the Father and Son
What did Adoptionism teach about Jesus?
Jesus was a mere human â€œadoptedâ€ by God
Who opposed Adoptionism?
St. Irenaeus and early Church Fathers
What truth about Jesus does the Church affirm in response to Adoptionism?
Jesus is truly God and truly man from conception
What did Arianism teach about Jesus?
Jesus is a created being, not fully God
Who taught Arianism and when?
Arius, early 4th century
Which council condemned Arianism?
Council of Nicaea (325 AD)
What truth about Jesus does the Church affirm in response to Arianism?
Jesus is consubstantial with the Father, fully divine
What did Apollinarianism teach about Jesus?
Jesus had a human body but not a human mind or soul
Who taught Apollinarianism and when?
Apollinaris of Laodicea, 4th century
Which council condemned Apollinarianism?
First Council of Constantinople (381 AD)
What truth about Jesus does the Church affirm in response to Apollinarianism?
Jesus is fully human and fully divine, with a human mind and soul
What did Nestorianism teach about Jesus?
Jesus is two separate persons, one human and one divine
Who taught Nestorianism and when?
Nestorius, early 5th century
Which council condemned Nestorianism?
Council of Ephesus (431 AD)
What truth about Jesus does the Church affirm in response to Nestorianism?
Jesus is one person with two natures, fully God and fully man (Hypostatic Union)
A belief or teaching that goes against the official and essential doctrines of the Church.
Heresy
What was the purpose of the Nicene Creed (325 AD)?
Combat Arianism; affirm Jesusâ€™ divinity
What was the purpose of the First Council of Constantinople (381 AD)?
Affirm Holy Spiritâ€™s divinity; oppose Pneumatomachi & Apollinarianism
What was the purpose of the Council of Ephesus (431 AD)?
Affirm unity of Christâ€™s person; Mary as Theotokos; oppose Nestorianism
Which Church Father opposed Arianism?
St. Athanasius
Which Church Father opposed Adoptionism?
St. Irenaeus
Which Church Father opposed Nestorianism?
St. Cyril of Alexandria
What truth about Jesus is clarified through these heresies?
Jesus is fully God and fully man
What is the Hypostatic Union?
One person, two natures of Christ
What does Consubstantial mean?
Of the same essence
Denies the divinity of the Holy Spirit; claims the Spirit is a created being.
Pneumatomachi
Teaches that Jesus was a mere human who was â€œadoptedâ€ by God at His baptism or resurrection.
Adoptionism
Denies that Jesus is fully God; says He was a created being and not co-eternal with the Father.
Arianism
Claims that Jesus had a human body but no human mind or soul; the Divine Logos replaced His rational soul.
Apollinarianism
Teaches that Jesus is two separate personsâ€”one human and one divineâ€”instead of one person with two natures.
Nestorianism
In the recent CLVED lesson, we are presented the different obstacles to 3 things, name them.

- Believing 
- Doing
- Worshipping
What are the 3 principal types of not believing

1. Denial that God exists
2. Special knowledge into one's fate and future
3. Natural self-centeredness or pride
What is the language of origin of the word "Atheist"
Greek
What is the word in which "atheist" is derived from?
Atheos
What does "Atheos" mean
Godless
Known as the world's newest major religion
the rise of "NONES"
What years did Blaise Pascal live?
Who proposed pascal's wager?
Blaise Pascal
Pascal's wager is proof of God's existence. T or F?
F
If pascal's wager isn't an argument for God's existence, what is it?
A practical decision-making argument

Divination

Magic

Deuteronomy 18:10-11

Natural self-centeredness or Pride
This philosophy doubts the truth of something
Skepticism

What is the source of this statement:

"This involves a catechesis that is Christ-centered, rooted in the living word of Scripture, and authentically Filipino and systematic"
PCP II 156

a "Renewed Catechesis"

Social apostolate and worship

"What modern person could possibly accept such old-fashioned beliefs"

Nones

Atheism

Agnosticism

Apollinarianism
Why do people in the new testament no longer do animal sacrifices
Because the ultimate offering is Jesus
Why is Jesus called the "lamb of god"
Because he is the ultimate sacrifice

St. Thomas Aquinas
Defined as the state of being unwilling/unable to believe in something
Incredulity

- Adoptionism

"The fool says in his heart, there is no God"

"Who is the liar? He who denies that Jesus is the Christ"

1. The faith we profess
2. The faith we live
3. The faith we celebrate

The faith we profess/creed
Defined as the way of living in everyday of life
The faith we live
Defined as the sacrament in which everyone now and then we celebrate
The faith we celebrate
Which word and from what language does the word "sacrament" come from?
"sacramentum", Latin
What does sacramentum mean?
Oath

Originally the word â€œ{{c1::sacramentum}}â€ refers to the
{{c2::obedience}} of the {{c2::soldiers}} to the {{c2::Roman Empire}} and
to the {{c3::gods}} and {{c3::goddesses}} in Rome.

Later in {{c1::2nd century}}, the word â€œsacramentumâ€ was
use by the {{c2::Early Christians}} which means â€œ{{c3::Ceremony

From what time period were the israelites under the roman empire?
Since from the birth of jesus until his death
What year was christianity officially declared as a religion
314 AD
Who officially declared christianity as a religion
Emperor Constantine
What was the word "sacramentum" referred to as during 314 AD? (2 words)
"symbol" and "celebration"
When was the word sacramentum used to refer to the 7 rituals of the church?
12th century

1. Baptism
2. Confirmation
3. Eucharist
4. Confession
5. Anointing of the sick
6. Holy Order 
7. Matrimony
Defined as the visible signs instituted by Christ to give grace
Sacrament
Defined as the sacraments are signs and means by which faith is expressed and strengthened
Visible signs
This phrase means christ himself founded the sacraments
Instituted by christ
A latin phrase meaning "from the work worked"
Ex opere operato
What does "Ex opere operato mean"?
"from the work worked"
This latin phrase refers to sacraments deriving their power from Christ's work rather than the role of humans
Ex opere operato
What is the latin phrase associated with sacraments
"ex opere operato"
What is the latin phrase associated with sacramentals?
"ex opera operantis"
The grace does not depend on how faithful the minister and the people gathered to celebrate
Sacraments
The grace will continue to flow through the power of Christ by the holy spirit
Sacraments
Who established the sacramentals?
The church
The effectiveness of grace will depend on how faithful the minister and the people gathered to celebrate
Sacramentals
The grace will flow if there is faith especially the one who will receive
Sacramentals
What are the 2 things required for a sacrament to be valid
The two things required for a sacrament to be valid
Matter and form
Defined as a material thing or element used during the rites
Matter
Matter is also known as?
accidents
Defined as a word uttered by minister every celebration
Form
Form is also known as
substance
What is the form of baptism
"I baptize you in the name of the father and of the son and of the holy spirit"
What is the matter of baptism
Water
What are the 3 ways water is used in baptism?
Immersion, infusion, or sprinkling
What is the form of confirmation
"Be sealed with the gift of the holy spirit"
Who says the form of confirmation?
Bishop or designated priest
What is the matter of confirmation? (2)
Holy Chrism and the laying on of hands by the bishop or a delegated priest
What is the form of the eucharist?
"This is my body which will be given up for you. Do this in memory of me..."
What is the matter of the eucharist (2)
Unleavened bread and grape wine
What is the form of confession?
"God the father of mercies, through the death and ressurection of his son..."
What is the matter of confession? (3)
Sins; Contrition and confession; priestly words of absolution
What is the form of marriage
"I do"
What is the matter of marriage?
Mutual consent and covenant to live together as husband and wife
What is the form of the holy order?
The bishop's specific consecratory prayer asking God for the outpourig of the Holy Spirit and his gifts...
What is the matter of the holy order
Laying on of the Bishop's hands with the consecratory prayer
What is the form of the anointing of the sick?
Prayer of the priest over the sick person for the grace of the Holy Spirit
What is the matter of anointing of the sick? (2)
Anointing with Holy Oil and Imposition of hands
What are the 2 purpose of sacraments

1. Man's sanctification
2. God's glorification
What are the 2 effects of the sacraments

1. To unite all the members of the Church
2. Total relationship with the father, and the son and the holy spirit

Canon 959

Bishop
Priest 
Deacon

Bishop

Bishop

Husband and Wife

Bishop

Bishop

Who are the extraordinary ministers of Baptism?
In emergencies, any person with the right intention even if they are not baptized
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Confirmation? (2)

1. Priests who are equivalent in law to a diocesan bishop for their subjects

2. Priests who are acting in danger of death for the person being confirmed or who have been specifically granted the faculty by the diocesan bishop
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Eucharist?
None
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Confession?
None
All priests can conduct confession. T or F?
F, a priest without faculties cannot do so
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Marriage?
None
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Holy Orders?
None
Who are the extraordinary ministers of Anointing of the sick?
none
Who are the recipients of Baptism?
Every person not yet baptized
Who are the recipients of Confirmation?
1. Every baptized person not yet confirmed
Which 3 sacraments form a unity?
Baptism, Confirmation, Eucharist
For without {{c1::confirmation}} and {{c1::eucharist}}, {{c1::Baptism}} is certainly valid and efficacious, but {{c2::Christian initiation}} remains incomplete
Who are the recipients of Eucharist? (2)

Baptized catholics who are in a state of grace

One who has committed a mortal sin has to first go to Confession before returing to receiving Holy Communion
Before people who have committed mortal sins have holy communion, what must they do
Go to confession
Who are the recipients of Confession?
A catholic who has reached the age of reason
What are the 4 elements of a valid catholic marriage?

1. The spouses are free to marry
2. They freely exchange consent
3. In consenting to marry, they have the intention to marry for live, to be faithful to one another, and be open to children
4. Their consent is given in the presence of two witnesses and before a properly authorized Church minister
Who are the recipients of holy orders? (2)

1. Baptized men
2. One who fulfill all the requirements needed for the ordination
Who are the recipients of anointing of the sick?
1. Anyone faithful begins to be in danger of death from sickness or old age
The anointing of the sick is not reserved for those on the point of death. T or F?
T

MIDES left home at the age of 21 to follow her calling and live a life of service.

1. Needle and thread
2. Strong faith in God

Needle and thread
Defined as MIDES' guiding light and strength in uncertain times
Strong faith in God
What was the underlying motive of MIDESâ€™ humble service?
Her motive was love of God and service to others, especially the poor and young women.

1. Sewing and embroidery
2. Catechism and Christian values
3. Household management
4. Virtues of humility and simplicity

practical livelihood skills

faith formation
Which skill is associated with household management?
cleanliness orderliness and responsibility
Which skill is associated with virtues of humilty and simplicity?
good character building
. What is the involvement of M. Ignacia and the early Beatas during the Philippine Revolution?

1. They opened the Beaterio as a refuge for the sick, wounded, and homeless during the revolution.

2. They offered prayers, guidance, and charity to support those suffering from the conflict.

is one who offers sacrifice on behalf of others

Baptism, Confirmation and Orders

Being baptized because of the prevalent "socialization process" instead of personal conviction
